page.title: 18LOCAL SADDLEWORTH DIALECT
page.content: Saddleworth is a Yorkshire parish with a Lancashire population, so is a 'mongrel' sort of parish! It is said to be strongly Yorkshire in customs, but the dialect is definitely strongly Lancashire, with much local 'slang'. Yorkshire & Lancashire writers have over the years been inspired by similar things & have striven to express them in the same way, but local terms abound. H. B. Whitehead, who was born in Diggle in 1890, has written several poems about the area, & also wrote 'Song of the Cenotaph' for the unveiling of the War Memorial at Pots & Pans in 1923. Typical local expressions include: 'He's bitten off more nur he con chew' if in difficulty; an avaricious person wants 'boath the hawpenny an' the gingerbread'; & 'it never rains but it pours' describes something excessive.
